title: 108_hr3702
content: The "Preserving Medicare for All Act of 2004" includes provisions such as authority to negotiate prices, guaranteed prescription drug benefits, and full reimbursement for qualified retiree prescription drug plans. It also repeals certain cost containment programs. The "Preserving Medicare for All Act of 2004" guarantees prescription drug benefits by providing access to a choice of qualified prescription drug coverage. The "Preserving Medicare for All Act of 2004" ensures access to a choice of prescription drug coverage, including a nationwide plan offered by the Secretary and at least 2 qualifying plans in each area. The requirement for different plan sponsors must be met to provide options for part D eligible individuals. The "Preserving Medicare for All Act of 2004" mandates access to prescription drug coverage through qualifying plans, including prescription drug plans, MA-PD plans, and a nationwide prescription drug plan offered by the Secretary. The Secretary, through the Administrator of the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services, will qualify and serve as a PDP sponsor to offer a nationwide prescription drug plan with basic coverage throughout the United States. The plan will be in addition to other prescription drug plans and the Secretary will establish a $35 premium for months in 2006 and specified amounts for subsequent years. The Secretary will offer a prescription drug plan with basic coverage nationwide, with premiums set at $35 for months in 2006 and specified amounts for subsequent years. The plan must meet solvency and capital adequacy standards, exercise necessary authorities, and ensure access by using regional or other pharmaceutical benefit managers. The Secretary may approve limited risk plans under section 1860D-11(f) to ensure access in certain areas. Section 1860D-11(g) of the Social Security Act is amended by striking it. SEC. 4. FULL REIMBURSEMENT FOR QUALIFIED RETIREE PRESCRIPTION DRUG PLANS. The text chunk discusses amendments to the Social Security Act related to the elimination of the True Out-Of-Pocket Limitation and the equalization of subsidies for qualified retiree prescription drug plans. The text chunk discusses adjustments to the Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement, and Modernization Act of 2003 to ensure payments are equivalent to what would have been made under section 1860D-15 for individuals in qualified retiree prescription drug plans, excluding the amendments from section 1202 of the Act. The Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement, and Modernization Act of 2003 is being adjusted by repealing the Comparative Cost Adjustment (CCA) Program and the MA Regional Plan Stabilization Fund. SEC. 6. REPEAL OF MA REGIONAL PLAN STABILIZATION FUND. Amendment to Section 1858 of the Social Security Act to remove subsections and redesignate others. Conforming amendment to Section 1851(i)(2) to reflect changes. SEC. 7. REPEAL OF COST CONTAINMENT PROVISIONS. Repealing cost containment provisions in the Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement, and Modernization Act of 2003. SEC. 7. REPEAL OF COST CONTAINMENT PROVISIONS.
